lead_org: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

unstructured.description: Men at risk of prostate cancer and have been advised to have a prostate biopsy and standard 3T prostate MRI OR have recently had a standard prostate MRI
Fit for undergoing all study protocol procedures which includes an ultrasound guided biopsy
Ability to understand and the willingness to sign a written informed consent and to comply with the protocol. If in question, an ethics consult will be obtained
Patients who have been treated using 5- alpha-reductase inhibitors at the time of study enrollment or 6 months prior to enrollment

Patients with previous history of prostate surgery or treatment for prostate cancer (interventions for benign prostatic hyperplasia/bladder outflow obstruction is acceptable). Patients who have had a prostate biopsy within the past year
Patients who have evidence of a urinary tract infection or history of acute prostatitis within the last 3 months.
Patients contraindicated to undergoing the MRI procedure e.g. pacemaker, estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) =< 50, automatic implantable cardiac defibrillators
History of any other medical condition precluding procedures described in the protocol

detail_description:
PRIMARY OBJECTIVE:
I. To assess the feasibility of upright multi parametric magnetic resonance imaging (MP-MRI) and compare the performance of upright MP-MRI in detecting clinically significant prostate cancer compared to prostate specific antigen (PSA) levels in men undergoing prostate biopsy and/or radical prostatectomy.

SECONDARY OBJECTIVES:
I. To compare performance characteristics of upright MP-MRI versus 3 tesla (3T) MP-MRI in detecting clinically significant prostate cancer (PCa) and PCa in general.
II. To determine whether patients experienced less claustrophobia and anxiety while undergoing upright MP-MRI compared to 3T MP-MRI.
III. To compare the diagnostic yield of using MP-MRI with thresholds PSA density used for detecting prostate cancer.
IV. To determine the ability of upright MP-MRI to rule out prostate cancer by testing if upright MP-MRI correctly identified side of prostate unaffected in men with pathological T2a and T2b disease.

EXPLORATORY OBJECTIVE:
I. To evaluate the correlation between MRI imaging parameters, histopathology, and molecular determinants of prostate cancer lesions.

OUTLINE: Patients are assigned to 1 of 2 groups.

GROUP I: Patients who recently had a standard 3T MP-MRI, undergo upright MP-MRI over 45 minutes within 12 weeks of standard 3T MP-MRI.

GROUP II: Patients who have been recommended to have an MRI are randomized to 1 of 2 arms.

ARM I: Patients undergo standard 3T MP-MRI over 45 minutes and then undergo upright MP-MRI over 45 minutes within 12 weeks of standard 3T MP-MRI.

ARM II: Patients undergo upright MP-MRI over 45 minutes and then undergo standard 3T MP-MR within 12 weeks of upright MP-MR.

After completion of study, patients are followed up every 3 months, 6 months or annually for 5 years or until the time require primary treatment for prostate cancer.
official_title: Feasibility and Efficacy of Upright MP-MRI for Prostate Cancer Screening

outcome_measures.name: Anxiety scores
outcome_measures.description: Will compare anxiety scores of participants on undergoing upright MP-MRI and 3T MP-MRI assessed by the patient reported outcomes (PRO) questionnaire. Will be assessed by Magnetic Resonance Imaging-Anxiety Questionnaire (MRI-AQ).

outcome_measures.name: Claustrophobic scores
outcome_measures.description: Will compare claustrophobic scores of participants on undergoing upright MP-MRI and 3T MP-MRI assessed by the patient reported outcomes (PRO) questionnaire. Will be assessed by Claustrophobic Questionnaire (CLQ).

outcome_measures.name: Number of correctly identified side
outcome_measures.description: Number of correctly identified side of prostate unaffected in men with pathological disease. Will assess upright MRI’s ability to correctly identify side of prostate unaffected in men with pathological T2a and T2b disease. High accuracy to discriminate correctly would indicate ability to rule out prostate cancer.

outcome_measures.name: Performance characteristics of upright MP-MRI
outcome_measures.description:
Performance characteristics by calculating sensitivity, specificity, NPV, PPV and AUC of Upright MP-MRI versus 3T MP-MRI in detecting PCa based on final histology of the RP specimen and targeted fusion biopsies.
We will use the updated Epstein’s criteria for clinically significant cancer which is PSA density < 0.15 ng/ml per gram, Gleason score =< 6, fewer than 3 positive cores, and < 50% of cancer involvement in any core.

outcome_measures.name: Performance characteristics specimen
outcome_measures.description: Will compare performance characteristics (sensitivity, specificity, PPV and NPV) of Upright MP-MRI with PSA density in detecting clinically significant prostate cancer, in men undergoing RRP, based on final histology of the radical prostatectomy (RP) specimen. Threshold PSA density > 0.15ng/mL will be used.

outcome_measures.name: Proportion of qualified images from upright magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
outcome_measures.description: Performance characteristics by calculating sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value (NPV), positive predictive value (PPV) and area under curve (AUC) of upright multiparametric (MP)-MRI versus 3T MP-MRI in detecting prostate cancer (PCa) based on final histology of the radical prostatectomy (RP) specimen and targeted fusion biopsies. Will use the updated Epstein’s criteria for clinically significant cancer which is PSA density < 0.15 ng/ml per gram, Gleason score =< 6, fewer than 3 positive cores, and < 50% of cancer involvement in any core.

arms.name: Group I (upright MP-MRI)
arms.description: Patients who recently had a standard 3T MP-MRI, undergo upright MP-MRI over 45 minutes within 12 weeks of standard 3T MP-MRI.

brief_summary: This study examines the performance of upright MP-MRI as a technique in screening prostate cancer compared to PSA and current MRI imaging in patients at risk of prostate cancer. PSA is the standard screening method for prostate cancer along with digital rectal exam. MRI has the potential to become a complementary screening tool to PSA. The upright MRI scanner uses a medium strength 0.6T magnet and is spacious and non-claustrophobic, unlike standard closed MRI scanners because of its unique geometric design (front and top open configuration). Patients sit upright as if sitting in a chair and can watch TV with an unobstructed view while having the scan performed. This study may potentially lead to the development of more accurate screening tools for prostate cancer.
brief_title: Upright MP-MRI Scan for Prostate Cancer Screening
study_population_description: Patients at risk of prostate cancer
